titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Attended at the Treasury-Office, and heard Mr: Lowrie— But was very late— Afterwards walk’d to Georgetown, with Mr: Hellen’s boy, and George— Prepared for my departure to-morrow morning. In the evening I had a long conversation with T. B. Johnson respecting the settlement of his father’s estate— It is left as well as all the family in a deplorable condition, from which with the best possible disposition it is not in my power to relieve them.

2. Soon after 6. this morning, the Stage called for me. I took leave of my wife and children who are to pass the Summer at Washington, and with Patty, set out for Baltimore. Dr: Archer a member of Congress from Maryland, and Mr: Higginbotham a clergyman of Annapolis were already in the Stage— We afterwards took in several other passengers— A young Mr: Hunt of New-Hampshire; Dr: Stevens, and General
Skinner were of the number— We had a tedious ride, with excessive bad roads;—and reached Baltimore, about 6. in the Evening— Here I found Mr: Purviance, Mr: Tracey and Mr: White— Mr: Harper, and Mr: Chase, the Judge’s Son, called upon me. Mr: Harper invited me to his house; but I was too much fatigued— Concluded with General Skinner and Mr: Hunt to go, by the Water Stage to Philadelphia.

3. Mr: Otis called at Evans’s this morning. He came in the other Stage yesterday from Washington, and proceeds with us. We embarked at 9 this morning in the Packet for French-town— Sailed with a fair wind; which soon changed and died away about noon to a calm. This continued the remainder of the day and all the evening, and night

4. At about 7. this morning we landed at French-town— The distance from Baltimore is 70 miles. In fair weather and wind, they run it in 6. or 7. hours. After Breakfasting at French-town we proceeded in two Stages to New Castle in the State of Delaware; the distance is 18 miles— There we arrived at 1/2 past 11. and immediately went on board the packet for Philadelphia; up Delaware river— The distance is 40 miles— We sailed with a very fine wind; which however in the course of two hours came, to the north-east, directly against us— We beat up the river against this wind, and with copious rain, untill 9 at Night, when we landed at Philadelphia— We first went to the Franklin’s Head tavern, and found the people all a-bed— We then went and took lodgings at Hardy’s tavern in Market-Street.

5. I intended to have stop’d a day at Philadelphia, but as Mr: Otis and General Skinner concluded to go on this morning; rather than part company I determined to go on with them. We took passage in the Swiftsure Stage, which travels a different road from that by which I have always gone heretofore. We left Philadelphia at eight this morning— Dined at New-Hope, and after travelling only 40 miles, stop’d for the night at Amwell; we should have gone eighteen miles further, to Somerset; but the road was so excessively bad, and the night so dark that we thought it too hazardous to proceed— We have in Company a frenchman who calls himself Duperron, a man of singular character and manners.

6. At 4 o’clock this morning we resumed our Journey— Breakfasted at Somerset, 18 miles— Dined at Springfield, 24. and reached Gifford’s at Newark 12 more, at about 7. in the evening. The roads have continued as bad, as possible; and almost the whole of the day it has rained plenteously with violent storms of wind— Patty was very unwell, and once fainted away in the carriage. I was not without apprehension of a return of her disorder— She recovered however so as to proceed on our way; but this was one principal inducement for stopping the night at Newark.

7. At 5 this morning we left Gifford’s, and between 7 and 8 got to Powles Hoek— We immediately cross’d the North river— I took leave of my travelling companions, and went with Patty to my Sister Smith’s; whom I found with her children at breakfast— Coll: Smith himself, is very unwell; and confined to his chamber with a severe cold and cough— Soon after my arrival, Dr: Eustis called in to see him, and sat with us an hour— I went down to Crane-Wharf, and found several Rhode Island Packets soon to sail— One of them was to go this afternoon, and Mr Otis had engaged his
passage in her— I took a passage also for Patty, and put her under Mr: Otis’s protection— Went on board the vessel with her; just on the point of her sailing, at 3. in the afternoon— Pass’d the Evening with Coll: Smith in his chamber— His brother James was there; and paid me 500 dollars on his brother Justus’s note to me.

8. Mr: King, and Mr: Wolcott, called to see me, and I had long conversations with them, principally on public affairs— I paid a visit to Mr: Burr, at his lodgings, in the City— He says if the Election were to be a fortnight later, he should probably succeed— Nothing could have induced him to let his name be held up as a Candidate for the Office of Governor of New-York, but the absolute necessity of interposing to save the Country from ruin by these family combinations &c &c &c.— Dr: Eustis dined with us. The Coll: came down to dinner, but was obliged to retire immediately afterwards— I spent the Evening with Mr: King.— Found Mr: Pickering there— Mr: Payne came in— His wife had this morning two sons, born at seven months— They were going on to-morrow or Tuesday in one of the Rhode-Island Packets.

9. Paid visits this morning to Mr: King, Mr: Wolcott and Mr: M’Cormick— Promised Mr: M’Cormick to send him a copy of the Supreme Court’s opinion in the case of Church and Hubbart.— Mr: Robert Bird called on me— I endeavoured without success to see Mr: M. L. Davis.— Received a letter from Mrs: Adams which I answered— Spent the Evening with Coll: Smith who is still confined to his chamber; excepting a couple of hours pass’d with Messrs: Clason, Gelston and Tompkins, the Assignees of Robert Bird.

10. Saw Mr: M. L. Davis this morning— Dined with Mr: King— Dr: Eustis and Mr: Payne were there— I spent the Evening with Mr: King, in particular conversation— The assignees of Robert Bird, were to have met me again; but some of them could not attend, and the meeting failed— The Packet Cordelia, Captain Anthony, in which I had taken passage, was also to have sailed this day; but was detained by contrary wind.

11. Still wind-bound— But this afternoon a change of weather took place; and we are to sail to-morrow morning, at 9 o’clock.— I saw Mr: Tompkins, and endeavoured to see Mr: Hoffman, on the business of Bird’s Bankruptcy; but could effect nothing satisfactory. Called again upon Mr: King, and walk’d with him— Read some English political pamphlets which he lent me.— Evening with Coll: Smith in his chamber.— Mr: King took charge of a letter from me to Mr: Williams.

12. Embarked on board the Packet Cordelia, Captain Anthony, and sailed for Providence, at 9 o’clock this morning— Weather fair; and wind rather scant— It soon freshened, and blew to a gale of wind; which continued by gusts and flows the whole day. Before dark we had reached the line of the forken Islands, or half the distance— The Packet Aurora, Captain Cahoon, sailed after us, and before night out-strip’d us— Mr: Pickering, is a fellow passenger— And also Mr: Murray the Universalist clergyman, and Mr: Collier, and his family— He is going to settle at the Baptist Church in Charlestown.

13. Last evening, the wind moderated, and became more favourable; at 5 this morning we came to off Newport and landed Mr: Murray, and one other passenger. The Aurora, Captain Cahoon, had reached the wharf, not more than a quarter of an hour before us— Three of his passengers came on board of our vessel— Captain Johnson and Mr: Hodge of Newbury-Port, and another person unknown to me.
We then proceeded on our passage, and expected to have arrived at Providence before 9 o’clock in the morning— But when we had got about ten miles on the way, the wind came round against us, and blew with great violence— At 11. in the morning, the tide also turned against us, and we were obliged to anchor, untill 4. in the afternoon— We then again got under way, and beat up the river against the wind, untill 7. The vessel now grounded within fifty rods of the wharf. Mr: Pickering, with several others of the passengers, determined to take a stage and go on immediately for Boston— But not being inclined to ride in the Night, I resolved to stay, and took my lodging at Aldrich’s— Met there a Mr: Pollen; an Englishman, of some singularity of character.

14. Between 7 and 8 this morning, the Mail Stage took me up; and soon after Mr: Collier with his family— There were also several other persons, and the carriage was crowded.— We dined at Walpole. Stop’d at Dedham; where I saw a young man of 18 lying dead— His name was Lewis— He had been kill’d, about two hours before, by an accident.— We came on the turnpike road from Dedham, and arrived in Boston between four and five o’clock in the afternoon. As we pass’d by the bottom of the Common, we very narrowly escaped running over a boy of 7 or 8 years old— I left the Stage, and descended at Whitcomb’s Coffee-House— Sent for W. S. Shaw, who came immediately to me— My father was in town; and had just dined at Mr: Smith’s, where I immediately went. Found Mr: Otis there.— I came out to Quincy, with my father and Louisa Smith— We got home before dark.— Found Mrs: Charles Adams, and her children here.— My brother remained in Boston

15. Heard Mr: Whitney of Hingham— Pass’d the remainder of the day at leisure— In the evening Mr: Beale and my Uncle Adams were here— I wrote a letter to my wife; and began to make up the arrears of my journal; which have run behind from the time I left Washington.

16. Went into Boston this morning— Stop’d at Neponset Bridge, where I found a Committee from the Court of Sessions, with Mr: Beale and Mr: Apthorp, a Committee from the Bridge Corporation, adjusting the indemnities with the proprietors of lands taken to make the road— Met my brother and Mr: Shaw coming out to Quincy— They returned to Boston with me— Occupied with business of various kinds in Boston— Dined with Mr: Quincy; and returned in the Evening with my brother— Found Mrs: Cranch, at my father’s.

17. Rained and stormed the whole day with so much violence as confined us altogether to the house— Dr: Tufts and his lady were here in the morning.— Settled accounts with him— Employed all day in writing, and arranging my accounts and papers.
18. Went out this morning with my gun; but without success— My brother was luckier— Bought some apple-trees— Unwell part of the day— My brother spent the evening abroad.

19. Went up to my farm this morning, and fixed upon a place for setting out an orchard— Saw William put down a number of apple-trees— Walked round the farm with Mr: Briesler— Met my brother, and returned home with him— Mr: Beale here in the Evening.

20. Went up to my farm and saw the remainder of my trees set out—47.— Went over the hills with my gun, and shot some birds— Came out into the Weymouth Turnpike— In the afternoon a Mr: Lazell came, with a subscription for the New-Bedford Turnpike; to which I subscribed for ten shares— Reading Gallatin on the finances of the U.S.— Boylston Adams here in the Evening— I promised Mr: T. Greenleaf to attend at the Sessions for the Town, on the petitions for New Roads.

21. Mrs: Charles Adams went to Boston this morning, intending to return to Newark— She took her youngest daughter Abby with her— My Mother and Mrs: Cranch accompanied her to Boston— Doctor Tufts called this forenoon to talk about the Middlesex Canal, and the Estate at Medford— We dined at Mr: C. Miller’s—Mr: Beale—D. and T. Greenleaf—G. Apthorp, Barrett, and Whitney, were the Company; with my father and brother.— I read and wrote but little this day.

22. North-East Storm— Rained almost the whole day— So violent that we were confined all day to the house. My brother went to hear Mr: Whitney in the afternoon; but there was no public service— Read part of Mr: Gallatin’s book; and wrote a great part of the day— In the Evening, I read some passages of Spenser’s Fairy Queen to my father.

23. Rain and Storm continued all this day— Confined to the House— Employed the day principally in writing; read but little.— Mr: T. Greenleaf called this afternoon, on the business for which I am to appear before the Court of Sessions— In the Evening, I read a couple of Cantos of the Fairy Queen.

24. My brother went to Dedham this morning, to attend the Courts of Common Pleas and Sessions which sit there this week— I intended to have gone to Boston— I was invited to a public dinner given to Mr: Gore— But the weather continuing foul and rainy, confined me again at home.— Wrote assiduously in the morning— Read part of Mr: Gallatin’s second pamphlet on the finances in the afternoon— Wrote a letter to my wife— And in the evening, continued my Senatorial catalogue.— Had 55 more trees set out in my new orchard.

25. Weather continued foul the greatest part of the day— I walk’d out however before dinner, with my gun; for about an hour. Mr: Greenleaf called on me this afternoon— Read and wrote; and in the Evening read 2 Cantos of the Faery Queen.

26. Went to Dedham with Mr: Black; to attend at the Court of Sessions, on an application for a new road through the Town of Quincy.— But the Court of Sessions did not sit— The Court of Common Pleas, to whom a great part of the business usually done by the Sessions was transferr’d by an Act of the last Session of the Legislature, was engaged in the trial of sundry small offences.— Dined at Gay’s tavern— Mr: and Mrs: Morton pass’d in the Stage from Providence— In the afternoon, I return’d, with Mr: Black to Quincy.— Read in the Evening 4 Cantos of the Faery Queen.

27. Went to Dedham again with Mr: Black—the Court continued business transferr’d from the Sessions to the Common Pleas— Towards Night, a report was at length read and delivered in, on the Quincy road— It is against both the roads petitioned for— But in favour of a middle road, between the two— The report is to be considered on the first Tuesday of June to which the Court adjourned— It was a scene of much confusion— I returned with Mr: Black, to Quincy; late in the Evening. My brother stays till to morrow.

28. Walk’d with my gun, great part of this forenoon; but with indifferent success— Was somewhat fatigued— Company of Gentlemen dined with us. My brother came home from Dedham with Mr: Lisle— Evening short—

29. Heard Mr: T. M. Harris of Dorchester; who dined with us— He gave me a proposal for publishing a literary miscellany; towards which he also desired my Assistance— Mr: Shaw came out from Boston this afternoon— In the Evening I went to Mr: Cranch’s; where I was caught in a violent thunder-storm— It continued so late that I lodged there.—

30. Returned home early this morning— Mr: Shaw returned to Boston— Mr: T. Greenleaf called— Spent the day chiefly in reading and writing— Began, an analysis of the Laws of the United States, in chronological order as enacted and published— Mr: W. Smith and Mr: T. Carter here this afternoon.

Day. The first half of the month, I was travelling from Washington to this place. Since here, I have not yet acquired any regularity in the employment of my time— I rise usually between 6 and 7. Breakfast about 7. Employ the forenoon in reading, or strolling about— Dine between 1 and 2. Afternoon and evening untill 10 at Night as the morning.— I have the means of more order, and better industry, which I hope to improve.
